title: Establishes certain crime of prostitution on or near school grounds
summary: Establishes the crime of loitering for the purpose of engaging in a prostitution offense on or near school grounds and specifies penalties therefor.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2040

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the penal law, in relation to increasing the penalties for
loitering for the purpose of engaging in a prostitution offense on
or near school grounds

SUMMARY:
This bill creates a new subdivision 4 of Section 240.37 which
increases the penalties for loitering for the purpose of promoting a
prostitution offense when such loitering occurs on or near school
grounds. School grounds are defined to mean in or on or within any
building, structure, athletic playing field, playground or land
contained within the real property boundary line of a public,
parochial or private licensed day care, nursery, elementary,
intermediate, junior high, vocational, or high school, or any area
accessible to the public located within one thousand feet of the real
property boundary line comprising any such school or any parked
automobile or other parked vehicle located within one thousand feet
of the real property boundary line comprising any such school. Also,
area accessible to the public is defined as sidewalks, streets,
parking lots, playgrounds, stores and restaurants. The first
violation of this subdivision will be a class A misdemeanor; repeated
violations will constitute a class E felony.

JUSTIFICATION:
Increasingly, particularly in inner-city school
districts, there has been a problem with persons loitering on or near
school grounds for the purposes of prostitution, drug sales and other
illegal purposes. Chapter 280 of the Laws of 1986 increased the
penalties for sale of controlled substances on or near school
grounds. This bill would similarly raise the penalties for loitering
for the purpose of promoting prostitution. What ever the social costs
of prostitution, there can be no denial of the fact that prostitutes
are a high risk group for both drug addiction and Acquired Immune
Deficiency Syndrome, and while an adult may be aware of the
consequences of engaging in sex-for-hire, minors should not be exposed
to the risks involved in such activities. Parents have a reasonable
expectation that their children will attend school in an area as safe
as possible. This legislation would put purveyors of prostitution on
notice that plying their trade on or near school grounds will result
in severe penalties.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None to the State.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the first of
November next succeeding the date on which it shall have become a law.
